verses.text: You shall not spread a false report. Do not join hands with a wicked person to be a false witness.
verses.comment: Stays true to the sense of 'spread a false report,' which conveys the Hebrew literally.

verses.text: You shall not follow a crowd to do evil, nor shall you testify in a dispute to turn aside after many to pervert justice.
verses.comment: 'Follow a crowd' reflects the Hebrew idea of going along with the majority for evil.

verses.text: You shall not show partiality to a poor man in his dispute.
verses.comment: Conveys the negative command to not favor the poor unfairly.

verses.text: If you meet your enemy’s ox or his donkey going astray, you shall surely bring it back to him.
verses.comment: Captures the restoration command and the context of an enemy.

verses.text: If you see the donkey of someone who hates you fallen under its load, you shall not pass by; you shall surely help him with it.
verses.comment: The phrase 'someone who hates you' matches the Hebrew.

verses.text: You shall not pervert the justice due to your poor in his dispute.
verses.comment: Stays literal and mirrors v.3 for parallelism.

verses.text: Keep far from a false matter, and do not kill the innocent and righteous, for I will not justify the wicked.
verses.comment: Maintains the strong warnings about falsehood and murder.

verses.text: You shall not take a bribe, for a bribe blinds those who see and twists the words of the righteous.
verses.comment: Use of 'blinds those who see' is a literal rendering of the metaphor.

verses.text: You shall not oppress a foreigner, for you know how it feels to be a foreigner, since you were foreigners in the land of Egypt.
verses.comment: 'How it feels to be a foreigner' matches the literal 'the soul of the foreigner.'

verses.text: For six years you shall sow your land and gather in its yield,
verses.comment: Simple, word-for-word translation.

verses.text: but the seventh year you shall let it rest and lie fallow, that the poor of your people may eat; and what they leave, the wild animals of the field may eat. In the same way, you shall do with your vineyard and your olive grove.
verses.comment: Reflects original structure; 'lie fallow' is literal.

verses.text: Six days you shall do your work, but on the seventh day you shall rest, so that your ox and your donkey may have rest, and the son of your female servant and the foreigner may be refreshed.
verses.comment: 'May be refreshed' renders the Hebrew idiom.

verses.text: Pay attention to all that I have said to you, and you shall not call upon the names of other gods, nor let them be heard on your lips.
verses.comment: 'Call upon the names' is close to literal sense.

verses.text: Three times in the year you shall keep a feast to me.
verses.comment: Follows Hebrew closely, 'keep a feast' is literal.

verses.text: You shall keep the Feast of Unleavened Bread. Seven days you shall eat unleavened bread, as I commanded you, at the appointed time in the month of Abib; for in it you came out of Egypt. And none shall appear before me empty-handed.
verses.comment: 'None shall appear...empty-handed' is literal.

verses.text: Also the Feast of Harvest, the firstfruits of your labors that you sow in the field, and the Feast of Ingathering at the end of the year, when you gather in your labors from the field.
verses.comment: Literal names for the agricultural feasts.

verses.text: Three times in the year all your males shall appear before the Lord GOD.
verses.comment: Literal, 'appear before the Lord GOD.'

verses.text: You shall not offer the blood of my sacrifice with leavened bread, nor shall the fat of my feast remain until morning.
verses.comment: 'Remain until morning' is a literal rendering.

verses.text: The first of the firstfruits of your land you shall bring into the house of the LORD your God. You shall not boil a young goat in its mother’s milk.
verses.comment: Closely follows Hebrew; retains dietary prohibition.

verses.text: See, I am sending an angel before you to guard you on the way and to bring you to the place which I have prepared.
verses.comment: 'See,' or 'behold,' is a literal marker; 'angel' is mal'akh.

verses.text: Pay attention to him and obey his voice; do not rebel against him, for he will not pardon your transgression, for my name is in him.
verses.comment: 'My name is in him' is literal and significant theologically.

verses.text: But if you truly obey his voice and do all that I speak, then I will be an enemy to your enemies and an adversary to your adversaries.
verses.comment: Retains parallelism and literal threat/promise structure.

verses.text: For my angel will go before you and bring you to the Amorites, the Hittites, the Perizzites, the Canaanites, the Hivites, and the Jebusites, and I will wipe them out.
verses.comment: Lists people groups as in Hebrew.

verses.text: You shall not bow down to their gods, nor serve them, nor do as they do, but you shall completely overthrow them and break their pillars in pieces.
verses.comment: Keeps repetition and commands strong and clear.

verses.text: You shall serve the LORD your God, and he will bless your bread and your water, and I will take sickness away from among you.
verses.comment: 'Bless your bread and your water' retains the metaphor.

verses.text: None shall miscarry or be barren in your land. I will fulfill the number of your days.
verses.comment: 'Fulfill the number of your days' is literal.

verses.text: I will send my terror before you, and will throw into confusion all the people against whom you come, and I will make all your enemies turn their backs to you.
verses.comment: 'Turn their backs' is literal Hebrew for fleeing.

verses.text: And I will send the hornet before you, which shall drive out the Hivite, the Canaanite, and the Hittite from before you.
verses.comment: 'Hornet' is kept literal, as in Hebrew.

verses.text: I will not drive them out from before you in one year, lest the land become desolate and the wild animals multiply against you.
verses.comment: Preserves literal development of conquest.

verses.text: Little by little I will drive them out from before you, until you have increased and inherit the land.
verses.comment: Parallel phrase to v.29; 'drive them out...inherit.'

verses.text: And I will set your border from the Red Sea to the sea of the Philistines, and from the wilderness to the River; for I will give the inhabitants of the land into your hand, and you shall drive them out before you.
verses.comment: 'The River' is a literal term for the Euphrates.

verses.text: You shall make no covenant with them or with their gods.
verses.comment: Parallel syntax with verse 24.

verses.text: They shall not dwell in your land, lest they make you sin against me. For if you serve their gods, it will surely be a snare to you.
verses.comment: 'Snare' kept literal as per original Hebrew word 'moqesh.'
